terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Portuguese countryside. Moderate elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional Portuguese event. Rolling terrain with moderate access, moderate costs, and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: 114 Gravel Race is a regional event in Portugal—rolling terrain with moderate elevation. The Portuguese countryside is nice and organization is solid, but the moderate access and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid Portuguese rolling gravel race. Worth it for European riders. Not practical for most international riders.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Europe—yes, it's solid. If you're international—there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better value: regional gravel races. For similar Portuguese terrain: Alentejo Gravel.

logistics.airport: Lisbon (LIS) or Porto (OPO) varies by location
logistics.food: Portugal has full dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: Portuguese rolling terrain requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: Cross-border start in Elvas, Portugal and finish in Badajoz, Spain creates obvious transportation complications with zero guidance provided. No information on nearest airports, parking strategy, or packet pickup locations leaves you guessing on basic race weekend logistics.

length.explanation: 123km hits the sweet spot for gravel racing — long enough to matter, short enough to avoid death march territory. Matthew Holmes covered the distance in 3:13:25, while Lucía González Blanco needed 3:36:14, suggesting 4-6 hours for most riders.

technicality.explanation: Course features 65% gravel and 35% paved roads through rolling terrain with no major sustained climbs. The steepest section is 6-7% for 1km, with the longest climb being 4km at 4-5% gradient — more about endurance than bike handling skills.

elevation.explanation: 864m of climbing over 123km is modest for gravel racing, with major climbs concentrated in the middle section. Starting at 300m and finishing at 150m with gentle rollers throughout keeps the elevation challenge manageable for most riders.

climate.explanation: Late March timing in Portugal-Spain border region typically offers mild spring temperatures ideal for long gravel efforts. The low elevation between 150-300m keeps weather moderate without altitude complications.

altitude.explanation: Maximum elevation of 300m at the start means sea-level racing with zero altitude impact on performance. Finishing at 150m in Badajoz keeps you firmly in the oxygen-rich zone throughout the course.

adventure.explanation: The only UCI gravel race starting in one country and finishing in another delivers cross-border exploration. Rolling through Portuguese dehesas, crossing international borders mid-race, and finishing along the Guadiana river creates exploration vibes.

prestige.explanation: 515 riders from 30 countries registered for 2025, including former MotoGP star Aleix Espargaro and gravel specialists like Annabel Fisher and Freddy Ovett. UCI Gravel World Series qualification adds legitimacy despite being one of 40+ qualifier events.

race_quality.explanation: Three feed zones at km 30, 55, and 93 show basic organization, but course specs remain inconsistent — UCI lists 123km/864m while race website claims 137km/1,370m. Elite finish margins of 1 second (men) and 21 seconds (women) suggest proper competitive execution.

experience.explanation: Starting at UNESCO World Heritage fortifications in Elvas and finishing at Guadiana Park in historic Badajoz creates cultural depth. The course passes through 'seemingly untouched nature reserves and farmed pastures' connecting medieval Portuguese and Spanish heritage sites.

community.explanation: Being part of the UCI series means legitimate qualifying opportunities for age-group riders chasing World Championships spots. The Portugal-Spain border theme creates natural camaraderie around the unique geography. But zero rider testimonials or race reports in the search results suggests the community buzz is limited to participants, not the broader gravel scene.

field_depth.explanation: Matthew Holmes used road professional experience to edge Jose Maria Sanchez Ruiz by one second after 3:13:25. The presence of former pros and gravel specialists like Annabel Fisher elevates competition beyond typical amateur fields.

value.explanation: €50-70 tiered entry fees are reasonable for a UCI-sanctioned event with World Championship qualifying opportunities. The cross-border logistics complexity and cultural heritage venues justify the cost for serious age-group competitors chasing qualification spots.

expenses.explanation: Cross-border logistics between Elvas and Badajoz create transportation headaches with no clear accommodation guidance provided. You're dealing with two countries and zero information on parking or packet pickup locations beyond the reasonable race entry fees.
